head.title: List of countries and territories by border/area ratio - Wikipedia

body.class: mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr mw-hide-empty-elt ns-0 ns-subject page-List_of_countries_and_territories_by_border_area_ratio rootpage-List_of_countries_and_territories_by_border_area_ratio skin-vector action-view

div.h1: List of countries and territories by border/area ratio

td.div: This table may be more easily updated if the rank-order column (1,2,3) is removed and a row number column is added instead. Alphabetical order may also help. See examples here.

This article does not cite any sources. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (June 2012) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

div.p: This is a list of countries and territories by border/area ratio. For each country or territory, the total length of the land borders and the total surface area are listed, as well as the ratio between these two parameters. A high border/area ratio means that the country or territory has a long border compared to its surface area. A border/area ratio of zero indicates that the country has no land borders.
Countries or territories that are connected only by bridges or other man-made causeways are not considered to have land borders.

a.title: Edit section: Border/area ratio

tr.td: Saint Helena Ascension and Tristan da Cunha (United Kingdom)
South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands (United Kingdom)

a.title: Edit section: Extremes

div.p: The countries with the highest border/area ratios are some of the smallest, non-island, nations of the world, such as Vatican City, Monaco and San Marino. Many island nations, lack any land borders and thus have a border/area ratio of zero.

a.title: Edit section: See also
How Long Is the Coast of Britain?
